JOHNS HOF'KINS UNIVERSITY
VOL. XVIII, NO. 29.

BALTIMORE, MD., JUNE 1, 1914.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS
NEW INTERFRAT. AGREEMENT

MORGAN WON TOURNAMENT
But Tennis Star Had to Play Hard to
Beat Crawford—Season Closed
in a Blaze of Glory.

The tennis schedule was concluded last week in a blaze of
glory. The tournament was finally
completed, and the team played the
last matches of its schedule.
The final round in the championship singles, in which Morgan and
Crawford were the contenders,
brought out some sterling play.
Morgan, who has not be defeated
in any college match this spring,
was naturally expected to win, but
it required some sterling play to
come through on top. Crawford
began with a rush and took the
first two sets, 6-4, 7-5. Here, however, Morgan's experience a n d
powers of endurance stood him in
good stead. He made his opponent
play his hardest, and the pace
proved too strong. Morgan won
the next three sets and the match,
6-4, 6-3, 6-2.
The consolations were completed
about two weeks ago and brought
out some surprises. In the semifinal round, Evitt, who is a beginner at the game, disposed of Powers, the winner in last year's consolations. However, he was forced
to bow to Merrick in the final
round, after four hotly-contested
sets. The finals in the doubles were
not so exciting, as the outcome was
a foregone conclusion. Morgan
and Crawford easily defeated Huck
and Beatty in straight sets.
By defeating Swarthmore on last
Tuesday by five matches to one the
Hopkins team closed an exceedingly successful season. Out of nine
maches, five were won, two tied and
only two lost. The schedule was
easily the most ambitious ever attempted. Michigan, by the rather
foxy trick of pitting its weakest
man against Morgan, managed to
earn a draw, each team getting two
singles and one doubles match. On
the day following the HopkinsMichigan play, Gettysburg was met
on the Homewood courts and defeated by the score of 4 to 2. The
last match of the season, that with
Swarthmore, was a walk-away for
Hopkins. Morgan beat Gittings,
6-2, 6-0; Crawford beat the Swarthmore captain, 6-2, 6-4; DuBray defeated Sproul, 9-7, o-6, 6-3; and
Hammond won from Gittings, 6-4,
6-1. The only match won by
Swarthmore was the doubles, in
which Hammond and Corner were
defeated, 6-4, 6-4. The Swarthmore team was dined at Roland
Park and returned home the same
evc fling.

co isiderably weakened by the grad-

NOVEL VACATION FOR HULBURT

ATHLETIC BOARD'S LAST MEETING

Eddie Will Be Official Log Taker onYacht
Vanitie in Trials for Selection of Cup
Defender Against Shamrock IV.

Awards Letters and Elects Graduate
Lacrosse and Track Managers for
Next Year's Teams.

The pressing question among
Hopkins students just now is how
the coming vacation is to be spent.
Some intend going to camps, a few
may cross the water, but by far the
majority will devote their time in
financially profitable occupations.
But it remained for E. 0. Hulburt,
graduate in mathematics and physics and former lacrosse star, to
select perhaps the most novel and
interesting summer employment yet
heard of around the University.
Hulburt has received the position
of official calculator on the yacht
Vanitie, one of the three swift sailing vessels which will compete for
the honor of defending the International Yacht Cup against Sir
Thomas Lipton's newest challenger,
Shamrock IV. Hulburt will leave
Baltimore to take up his duties on
June 6. His special work will be
the keeping of all the official records of the Vanitie, the reading of
the speedometer, the tilt, the heel
and the wind pressure, and the
computation of the speed attained
under different atmospheric conditions. The trials will consist of
daily trips on Long Island Sound.
In addition, a series of regattas
will be held during the summer at
Newport, and upon the results
made in these by the three contenders will depend the choice of
the American cup defender. If the
Vanitie is chosen to compete against
the foreigner, Hulburt will remain
aboard during the international
race, which will take place in September. By that time the Hopkins
man will have become thoroughly
hardened to ocean life and, with his
thorough mathematical training,
should prove a valuable addition to
the crew of the yacht.

The executive board of the General Athletic Association held its last
meeting of the year on Wednesday
in the Trophy Room to award honorary letters to members and managers
of the three spring teams. Thirtythree members of the lacrosse, track
and baseball squads received the"H,"
and fourteen others the "H. A. A."
Roger Howell, Andrew Hilgartner
and George E. Dorsey, managers
of the lacrosse, baseball and track
teams, respectively, were awarded
the "H. M."
The letters and sweaters will not
be given to the successful students
until the annual spring blow-out
and bonfire, which will be held at
Homewood shortly after the conclusion of the final examinations.
Plans for the celebration are in
the hands of a special committee.
Captains and coaches will make
speeches and ice cream and cake
will be served.
After the awarding of the letters
by the Athletic Board, important
elections were held. George E.
Dorsey, of the graduating class,
was elected graduate manager for
the coming season, to succeed Paul
0. Carter. Dorsey has been interested in athletics ever since his
entrance into the University, and
filled the position of assistant manager of the track team in 1913-14
and that of manager during the past
year.
Everard Deems, '15, who has
been assistant manager of the track
team for two years, was unanimously elected as manager of the
team. Deems, is thoroughly familiar
with track and field athletics and
will make an able successor to the
new graduate manager.
Roger Howell's place as manager of the lacrosse team will be
filled next year by Hiram Woodward, '16, who has been assistant
manager of the team for two years
and has also played on the scrub lacrosse team.

uation of DuBray and Crawford
from the Medical School and of
Hammond and Corner from the
undegraduate department, there
still remains much good material at
the University.

Committee Now Drawing Up New Code.
Will Have No Definite Time for
the "Rushing Season."

The Interfraternity Agreement,
recently threatened with dissolution
because of differences of opinion
among the various chapters in the
University, has been agreed to by
all fraternities but one (Delta Phi),
which is not at present favorable to
any rules governing the "rushing"
of freshmen. Thus it will be finally ratified at a meeting of the Board
some time this week. The work of
the wording and drawing up of the
agreement is in the hands of a committee, which is now at work.
The new set of "rushing rules"
will differ materially from those of
the two previous years. There will
be no definite "rushing season." In
the place of this there is to be substituted a period of time (from the
beginning of the college year until.
the second Monday after the Y. M..
C. A. reception) in which no freshman may be taken into a fraternity
house or talked to on fraternity
matters; in other words, a closed
season for freshmen, during which
they are supposed to be getting
settled and looking around for
themselves.
The penalties for violation of the
agreement will probably remain the
same. At present they are considered severe by some, and act as
a sure safeguard against infringment by the separate chapters.
The discussions of the interfraternity rules during the last few
months has been keen 'at times and
it looked once as if the whole business would explode and all chapters
return to the entertainment and
pledging of high school boys—a
custom somewhat unwise and inexpedient.
Each fraternity stood out for a
different system of "rushing," but
finally a compromise was hit upon
which would meet the concessions
of both the conservative and the
progressive elements. This once
done, the settlement of the matter
was quick.
The Board expects to have the
new set of rules printed in time for
distribution among the various nearby prep. schools, and to distribute
them among the incoming freshman class next fall.
The agreement has been in existence three years and has been radically changed each year. At last it
seems that a sensible plan, and one
which is well suited to the needs of
Hopkins, has been evolved and the
new rules are likely ,to remain in
force for some time.

ENGLISH LITERATURE.
EDUCATION,

For four consecutive nights the hotel
man had watched his fair, timid guest fill
her pitcher at the water cooler.
"Madam," he said, on the fifth night,
"if you would ring, this would be done
for you."
"But where is my bell?" asked the
lady.
"The bell is beside your bed," replied
the proprietor.
"That the bell!" she exclaimed. "Why,
the boy told me that was the fire alarm,
and I wasn't to touch it on any account."

Old Farmer Corntossel had taken
some of the summer boarders out for
a drive. The poor old horse was slow
at best, and every now and then he
would stop altogether.
"What's the matter with him?" asked
a boarder. "Is he balky?"
"No, 'tain't that," explained the old
man. "The trouble with him is that he
is so darn afraid somebody will say
'Whoa!' without his hearin' it, that he's
always stoppin' to listen."
A number of men were having a social
time, when a big German declared that
he could drink ten glasses of beer.
One man offered to bet ten dollars that
he couldn't do it.
"You shust wait till I pe pack a leetle,"
said the German, as he started across
the street to another saloon. Returning
in a few minutes the bet was made and
the ten glasses of beer were disposed of
as a thirsty cow swallows water.
The disgusted loser paid the bet ana
left.
"I had a dead cinch," remarked the
big German, as he winked the other eye.
"How so?" inquired some one.
"I vent oud first and tried it."

Willie was struggling through
the story in his reading lesson.
"No, said the captain," he read, "it
was not a sloop. It was a larger
vessel. By the rig I judged her to
be a-a-a-a-a--"
The word was new to him.
"Barque," supplied the teacher.
Still Willie hesitated.
"Barque!" repeated the teacher,
this time sharply.
Willie looked as though he had
not heard aright. Then, with an
apprehensive glance around the
class, he shouted:
"Bow-wow !"

Mrs. Brown—I so admire your husband, Mrs. Higgins. He is so amiable.
Mrs. Higgins—You must have met
some other Mr. Higgins.
An Irishman wag" mounted on a mule
which was kicking rather freely. The
mule finally got its hoof caught in the
stirrup, when the Irishman excitedly remarked: "Well, begorra, if you're goin'
to get on, I'll get off."
At a recent teacher's examination in
grammar, one of the questions called for
an illustration of an indirect object. The
following sentence w a s given: "She
threw a stone at a rooster and hit a hen.
Hen is the indirect object."
The vender of an eye wash wrote to
a good customer for a recommendation
for his medicine. In a few days it came:
"Dear Doctor—I have used ninety-five
bottles of your valuable eye wash. When

7

I began, I could not see my best friend;

NEW YORK
CLOTHING HOUSE

row I think I can see my finish."

Scotch Lady—Thomas, I wonder you
don't get married; you have got a nice
house and a comfortable situation, and
all you want to complete it is a wife.
You know Adam, who was the first
gardener, had a wife.
Thomas—That's quite richt, mum; but
Adam didn't keep his job long after he
got a wife.
Mr. Jones had for some time been
missing a number of his finest hens. He
lay in wait for the intruder, and one
night, hearing a noise in the direction
of the chicken house, he hurried forth.
When he reached the door of the building he shouted:"Who's in there ?" There
was a pause, then far back under the
roosts the faint voice of a very frightened Rastus answered: "Nobody but us
ickens."

"G-g-g-good-evening," said the
young man who had come to speak
to the young girl's father.
"Good-evening," said the father.
"You look a little nervous. How
do you feel?"
"Flattered," said the young man.
"I was afraid I looked scared to
death."—Penn State Froth.

JOHNS HOF'KINS UNIVERSITY
VOL. XVIII, NO. 29.

BALTIMORE, MD., JUNE 1, 1914.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS
NEW INTERFRAT. AGREEMENT

MORGAN WON TOURNAMENT
But Tennis Star Had to Play Hard to
Beat Crawford—Season Closed
in a Blaze of Glory.

The tennis schedule was concluded last week in a blaze of
glory. The tournament was finally
completed, and the team played the
last matches of its schedule.
The final round in the championship singles, in which Morgan and
Crawford were the contenders,
brought out some sterling play.
Morgan, who has not be defeated
in any college match this spring,
was naturally expected to win, but
it required some sterling play to
come through on top. Crawford
began with a rush and took the
first two sets, 6-4, 7-5. Here, however, Morgan's experience a n d
powers of endurance stood him in
good stead. He made his opponent
play his hardest, and the pace
proved too strong. Morgan won
the next three sets and the match,
6-4, 6-3, 6-2.
The consolations were completed
about two weeks ago and brought
out some surprises. In the semifinal round, Evitt, who is a beginner at the game, disposed of Powers, the winner in last year's consolations. However, he was forced
to bow to Merrick in the final
round, after four hotly-contested
sets. The finals in the doubles were
not so exciting, as the outcome was
a foregone conclusion. Morgan
and Crawford easily defeated Huck
and Beatty in straight sets.
By defeating Swarthmore on last
Tuesday by five matches to one the
Hopkins team closed an exceedingly successful season. Out of nine
maches, five were won, two tied and
only two lost. The schedule was
easily the most ambitious ever attempted. Michigan, by the rather
foxy trick of pitting its weakest
man against Morgan, managed to
earn a draw, each team getting two
singles and one doubles match. On
the day following the HopkinsMichigan play, Gettysburg was met
on the Homewood courts and defeated by the score of 4 to 2. The
last match of the season, that with
Swarthmore, was a walk-away for
Hopkins. Morgan beat Gittings,
6-2, 6-0; Crawford beat the Swarthmore captain, 6-2, 6-4; DuBray defeated Sproul, 9-7, o-6, 6-3; and
Hammond won from Gittings, 6-4,
6-1. The only match won by
Swarthmore was the doubles, in
which Hammond and Corner were
defeated, 6-4, 6-4. The Swarthmore team was dined at Roland
Park and returned home the same
evc fling.
.i'hough the tennis team will be
co isiderably weakened by the grad-

NOVEL VACATION FOR HULBURT

ATHLETIC BOARD'S LAST MEETING

Eddie Will Be Official Log Taker onYacht
Vanitie in Trials for Selection of Cup
Defender Against Shamrock IV.

Awards Letters and Elects Graduate
Lacrosse and Track Managers for
Next Year's Teams.

The pressing question among
Hopkins students just now is how
the coming vacation is to be spent.
Some intend going to camps, a few
may cross the water, but by far the
majority will devote their time in
financially profitable occupations.
But it remained for E. 0. Hulburt,
graduate in mathematics and physics and former lacrosse star, to
select perhaps the most novel and
interesting summer employment yet
heard of around the University.
Hulburt has received the position
of official calculator on the yacht
Vanitie, one of the three swift sailing vessels which will compete for
the honor of defending the International Yacht Cup against Sir
Thomas Lipton's newest challenger,
Shamrock IV. Hulburt will leave
Baltimore to take up his duties on
June 6. His special work will be
the keeping of all the official records of the Vanitie, the reading of
the speedometer, the tilt, the heel
and the wind pressure, and the
computation of the speed attained
under different atmospheric conditions. The trials will consist of
daily trips on Long Island Sound.
In addition, a series of regattas
will be held during the summer at
Newport, and upon the results
made in these by the three contenders will depend the choice of
the American cup defender. If the
Vanitie is chosen to compete against
the foreigner, Hulburt will remain
aboard during the international
race, which will take place in September. By that time the Hopkins
man will have become thoroughly
hardened to ocean life and, with his
thorough mathematical training,
should prove a valuable addition to
the crew of the yacht.

The executive board of the General Athletic Association held its last
meeting of the year on Wednesday
in the Trophy Room to award honorary letters to members and managers
of the three spring teams. Thirtythree members of the lacrosse, track
and baseball squads received the"H,"
and fourteen others the "H. A. A."
Roger Howell, Andrew Hilgartner
and George E. Dorsey, managers
of the lacrosse, baseball and track
teams, respectively, were awarded
the "H. M."
The letters and sweaters will not
be given to the successful students
until the annual spring blow-out
and bonfire, which will be held at
Homewood shortly after the conclusion of the final examinations.
Plans for the celebration are in
the hands of a special committee.
Captains and coaches will make
speeches and ice cream and cake
will be served.
After the awarding of the letters
by the Athletic Board, important
elections were held. George E.
Dorsey, of the graduating class,
was elected graduate manager for
the coming season, to succeed Paul
0. Carter. Dorsey has been interested in athletics ever since his
entrance into the University, and
filled the position of assistant manager of the track team in 1913-14
and that of manager during the past
year.
Everard Deems, '15, who has
been assistant manager of the track
team for two years, was unanimously elected as manager of the
team. Deems, is thoroughly familiar
with track and field athletics and
will make an able successor to the
new graduate manager.
Roger Howell's place as manager of the lacrosse team will be
filled next year by Hiram Woodward, '16, who has been assistant
manager of the team for two years
and has also played on the scrub lacrosse team.

uation of DuBray and Crawford
from the Medical School and of
Hammond and Corner from the
undegraduate department, there
still remains much good material at
the University.

Committee Now Drawing Up New Code.
Will Have No Definite Time for
the "Rushing Season."

The Interfraternity Agreement,
recently threatened with dissolution
because of differences of opinion
among the various chapters in the
University, has been agreed to by
all fraternities but one (Delta Phi),
which is not at present favorable to
any rules governing the "rushing"
of freshmen. Thus it will be finally ratified at a meeting of the Board
some time this week. The work of
the wording and drawing up of the
agreement is in the hands of a committee, which is now at work.
The new set of "rushing rules"
will differ materially from those of
the two previous years. There will
be no definite "rushing season." In
the place of this there is to be substituted a period of time (from the
beginning of the college year until.
the second Monday after the Y. M..
C. A. reception) in which no freshman may be taken into a fraternity
house or talked to on fraternity
matters; in other words, a closed
season for freshmen, during which
they are supposed to be getting
settled and looking around for
themselves.
The penalties for violation of the
agreement will probably remain the
same. At present they are considered severe by some, and act as
a sure safeguard against infringment by the separate chapters.
The discussions of the interfraternity rules during the last few
months has been keen 'at times and
it looked once as if the whole business would explode and all chapters
return to the entertainment and
pledging of high school boys—a
custom somewhat unwise and inexpedient.
Each fraternity stood out for a
different system of "rushing," but
finally a compromise was hit upon
which would meet the concessions
of both the conservative and the
progressive elements. This once
done, the settlement of the matter
was quick.
The Board expects to have the
new set of rules printed in time for
distribution among the various nearby prep. schools, and to distribute
them among the incoming freshman class next fall.
The agreement has been in existence three years and has been radically changed each year. At last it
seems that a sensible plan, and one
which is well suited to the needs of
Hopkins, has been evolved and the
new rules are likely ,to remain in
force for some time.

ENGLISH LITERATURE.
EDUCATION,

For four consecutive nights the hotel
man had watched his fair, timid guest fill
her pitcher at the water cooler.
"Madam," he said, on the fifth night,
"if you would ring, this would be done
for you."
"But where is my bell?" asked the
lady.
"The bell is beside your bed," replied
the proprietor.
"That the bell!" she exclaimed. "Why,
the boy told me that was the fire alarm,
and I wasn't to touch it on any account."

FRENCH,
GERMAN,
GREEK ARCHAEOLOGY,

The utmost
in style, fit
and service.

GREEK LITERATURE,
HISTORY,
LATIN,
MANUAL TRAINING,
MATHEMATICS,

Old Farmer Corntossel had taken
some of the summer boarders out for
a drive. The poor old horse was slow
at best, and every now and then he
would stop altogether.
"What's the matter with him?" asked
a boarder. "Is he balky?"
"No, 'tain't that," explained the old
man. "The trouble with him is that he
is so darn afraid somebody will say
'Whoa!' without his hearin' it, that he's
always stoppin' to listen."
A number of men were having a social
time, when a big German declared that
he could drink ten glasses of beer.
One man offered to bet ten dollars that
he couldn't do it.
"You shust wait till I pe pack a leetle,"
said the German, as he started across
the street to another saloon. Returning
in a few minutes the bet was made and
the ten glasses of beer were disposed of
as a thirsty cow swallows water.
The disgusted loser paid the bet ana
left.
"I had a dead cinch," remarked the
big German, as he winked the other eye.
"How so?" inquired some one.
"I vent oud first and tried it."

Oct. 1—First printing, 5,000 copies—advance sales very poor.
Nov. 1—Anthony Comstock condemns book.

copies.—The Masses.
Willie was struggling through
the story in his reading lesson.
"No, said the captain," he read, "it
was not a sloop. It was a larger
vessel. By the rig I judged her to
be a-a-a-a-a--"
The word was new to him.
"Barque," supplied the teacher.
Still Willie hesitated.
"Barque!" repeated the teacher,
this time sharply.
Willie looked as though he had
not heard aright. Then, with an
apprehensive glance around the
class, he shouted:
"Bow-wow !"

a rapid transit.—Harvard Lampoon.

Mrs. Brown—I so admire your husband, Mrs. Higgins. He is so amiable.
Mrs. Higgins—You must have met
some other Mr. Higgins.
An Irishman wag" mounted on a mule
which was kicking rather freely. The
mule finally got its hoof caught in the
stirrup, when the Irishman excitedly remarked: "Well, begorra, if you're goin'
to get on, I'll get off."
At a recent teacher's examination in
grammar, one of the questions called for
an illustration of an indirect object. The
following sentence w a s given: "She
threw a stone at a rooster and hit a hen.
Hen is the indirect object."
The vender of an eye wash wrote to
a good customer for a recommendation
for his medicine. In a few days it came:
"Dear Doctor—I have used ninety-five
bottles of your valuable eye wash. When

7

I began, I could not see my best friend;

NEW YORK
CLOTHING HOUSE

row I think I can see my finish."

Scotch Lady—Thomas, I wonder you
don't get married; you have got a nice
house and a comfortable situation, and
all you want to complete it is a wife.
You know Adam, who was the first
gardener, had a wife.
Thomas—That's quite richt, mum; but
Adam didn't keep his job long after he
got a wife.
Mr. Jones had for some time been
missing a number of his finest hens. He
lay in wait for the intruder, and one
night, hearing a noise in the direction
of the chicken house, he hurried forth.
When he reached the door of the building he shouted:"Who's in there ?" There
was a pause, then far back under the
roosts the faint voice of a very frightened Rastus answered: "Nobody but us
ickens."

"G-g-g-good-evening," said the
young man who had come to speak
to the young girl's father.
"Good-evening," said the father.
"You look a little nervous. How
do you feel?"
"Flattered," said the young man.
"I was afraid I looked scared to
death."—Penn State Froth.
